you made an error in your video. they dont have hexnocular vision. they have ommatidia (compound eyes). the dot we see is just the spot directly facing us and thus with the least light getting reflected. they actually have what functionally amounts to 360 degree vision in all axies. granted, the ommatidia are split into 6 regions, 3 in each eye, but they do not have pupils at all

see those black spots..? they are an optical illusion..... The black dots on the eyes of the praying mantis are an optical illusion, called a pseudopupil—they occur as a result of light being absorbed and reflected in the eye. This results in the illusion that the eyes are always looking at you.

TL;DR: Mantis shrimp have compound eyes with up to 10000 ommatidia and these dark spots have NOTHING to do with pupils (explanation below)

I have to inform you that there are some mistakes in the part where you talk about the hexnocular vision. Mantis shrimp have compound eyes which are made up of up to 10000 single eyes (ommatidia). The word hexnocular suggest only six eyes and while the term is also used in different sources it would have been vitaly important to clarify that those are modified compound eyes. Furthermore the video says that "the black spots in the eyes, work just like human pupils" which is just flat out wrong. The black spots that you can see in compound eyes are the dark pigments of the ommatidia which the observer is direktly looking into (which only works at a direct angle) because of the angle you cannot see the pigment in the remaining Omatidia resulting in the illusion of a dark spot following the observer. The pupil of a human eye has a completely different function and structure and should therefore not be compaired to this penomenon.
I really dont want to be nitpicky but it annoys me to see something like this in your videos which are usually very well researched. The real tragedy is that in a educational video primarily about the eyes of the mantis shrimp you managed to not only leave out a vital part of its anatomy, you also made statements which directly lead to false assumtions for the viewers (especially unexperienced). This is a real shame because most of these people will probably never question what they heard in the video and thereby miss out on the truth of the 10000 eyes of the mantis shrimp (which is obviously way cooler than 6 eyes). Finally I know that this is a old video and probably nobody will read this but I would very much appreciate it if you could add in a popup in the video (youtube has this function) or something that clarifies the compound nature of these magnificent eyes.

Depth perception is not created from having two eyes. People with one functioning eye can have depth perception. It's created as the brain learns how to interpret shadows and movement. A channel like this should know that. The lack of depth on a screen is due to the fact that everything on the screen moves the same relative to the viewer, so the brain has to be tricked into seeing depth through various forms of 3D technology.

Nice video. One error was the bit about pupils though. They have compound eyes composed of thousands of individual ommatidia. They don't have pupils. The black pseudopupil spots are an optical effect. That's why they always face you when you look at them. You see the same effect in other compound eyes, see praying mantises for an example.

The bit about the circulary polarized light is a bit misleading. The light isn't LITERALLY "spinning through space like a helix." Light is considered to be circularly polarized if:

- the light is composed of waves polarized along two perpendicular planes
- the waves are of equal amplitude
- the waves are 90 degrees out of phase with each other

Deep Look: @ Time mark 1:45/3:59 after looking at Peacock smasher mantis shrimp's compound eyes each compound eye cell on the surface is a small hexagonal opening they appear to turn black when the observer is looking straight into that particular opening well they tend to behave as a light trap so they appear to be black but only the ones being observed strait on that's why the black spots appear to move and that shrimp dosen't get such a detailed image of the world like we do . I used to work in an aquarium store many years ago, one evening we had a shipment of "live rock" come in (rocks picked up from reefs that have interesting things growing on them, they're popular with people who keep salt water aquariums.)  One of those rocks had a mantis shrimp hidden in it, we only found out about that the next morning though.  The mantis had come out of whatever piece of rock it had been hiding in and had busted the glass on the aquarium, everything that was in there was lying on the floor slowly drying out.

Now I could be wrong about this... but as far as I'm aware, those black spots mentioned around 1:09 are actually known as "pseudopupils." they are clusters of ommatidia (mini-eyes) that only APPEAR to be pupils because their optical axis is aligned with the camera/observer, so they absorb all incoming light and appear black. I guess what i'm saying is, its a bit misleading to call them pupils since in reality each tiny eye is like a pupil , and the black part just LOOKS like a pupil from that angle. although I guess im being a bit semantic here haha...

Uh... where in the world do you get the idea that they have "hexnocular vision"? Mantis shrimp have compound eyes. Each o those little facets on the eyes is a single eye, and they cannot close them. The black dots are NOT analogous to pupils, they are simply an artefact of the way light reflects (or doesn't) off of the eyes.
Maybe you got confused because each of the central bands has six rows of ommatidia (the individual eyes that make up the entire compound eye)? Of course, those are just the ROWS, and only the rows in the central band. Each row has multiple omatidia, and there are multiple rows on the sides adjacent to the central band.

1:07 I'm worried that some people might misunderstand this analogy. The black spots are just where the mantis shrimp's eye takes light in from the direction of the observer. The mantis shrimp doesn't track objects using its black spots. All facets of each compound eye take in light simultaneously from their respective directions. The black spots would simultaneously be in different places to different observers.

Hands down the best mantis shrimp video out there - a perfect, simple and understandable explanation of how their circularised polarised vision detection works and what that means. :)

In addition to their epic eyesight and speed, their telsons (the shell on their back) is incredibly strong and engineered in such a way to protect them from the blows of other mantis shrimps (as they tend to crack each other blows there).
Their microstructures are fascinating, and have great ways of preventing cracks from forming and propagating, which means that they also have one of the most resistant carapaces out of the animal kingdom.
One more way they are epically cool. :)
